data.title: Roald Dahl: Beguiling Fizzing Giant
data.meta_description: This giant of a human sold over 300 million books — inspiring generations of children worldwide to embrace their quirks, passions, flaws, and dreams.
data.text:
Critical Bio | Author

Roald Dahl was one of my favorite authors when I was a child.

Did you know he was 6 feet 6 inches tall?

This giant of a human sold over 300 million books — inspiring generations of children worldwide to embrace their quirks, passions, flaws, and dreams.

My favorites were Matilda, The BFG, The Witches, and Danny, the Champion of the World.

How do we reconcile his beautiful creations of whimsy with the dark parts of his life — anti-semitism, marital infidelity, and accusations of racist and sexist stories?

Was this life-long chocolate evangelist merely human — a man of inconsistency and occasionally questionable behavior? Or should we posthumously condemn and cancel his legacy — resign it to the flames?

Knowing what we know about him now, should I read his works to my nieces and nephew? Can I enjoy his books without shame? Should I?

This article is my attempt to answer the following questions:
